column2: More than $400,000,000 in gold and dollar and other foreign exchange which Mexico accumulated during the war will be conserved primarily to foster a reasonable industrialization of the country and will not be spent on consumer goods and luxuries, Dr. Eduardo Suarez, Secretary of the Treasury of Mexico, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--A housing subcommittee of the Senate Education and Labor Committee, acting with dispatch, approved after a brief hearing today a bill introduced by Senator James M. Mead, Democrat of New York,...

Pochip Properties, Inc., bought the four one and two-story factory buildings at 240-250 Greene Street between Oakland and Provost Streets, Brooklyn, from Fe Arky and Frances Arky Anderson. The buildings occupy a plot 110 by 100 feet. Sidney M. Spero was attorney for the buyer and the Hom Title Guaranty Company insured the title.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 15--While the Indians in Natal, where Mohandas K. Gandhi first pondered over political philosophy, are demonstrating noisily against restrictions, the Negroes in Orlando, a suburb of Johannesburg in the Transvaal, are applying passive resistance, as advocated by Mr. Gandhi.

Miss Anne Nevin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Paul Nevin of 253 East Forty-ninth Street, was married yesterday afternoon to Ward B. Chamberlin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward B. Chamberlin of South Norwalk, Conn., in St. James Episcopal Church.

The American Water Color Society, whose seventy-ninth annual exhibition now is open at the National Academy of Design, will hold painting demonstrations tomorrow afternoon from 3 to 7 o'clock, in which several members will participate.

Assistant Chief Inspector John J. Ryan was appointed yesterday to be second deputy commissioner of the Police Department, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced, and will be sworn in at 11 A. M. today by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall. Inspector Ryan succeeds Francis J. Kaer, retired.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--A detailed picture of the international economic position of the United States and the commitments it has made "in the role of world's banker," was requested from President Truman in a resolution presented to the Senate today by eight of the ten Republican members of the Appropriations Committee.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 15-The New Jersey Consumer Advisory Committee of the Office of Price Administration, meeting today in the Newark Museum, set March 10 to 16 as the tentative date for "Anti-Inflation Week," when "the people of the State will be mobilized to act for their own protection." Mrs. Helen P. Freeman of the Hudson County Citizens Council on Legislation presided.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court upheld unanimously yesterday the right of Johannes Steel, American Labor party candidate, to run for Representative in the Nineteenth Congressional District, affirming without opinion the ruling of Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr., who had dismissed a petition to disqualify Mr. Steel on the ground that he had been naturalized as Herbert Steel.

Willie Joyce, Gary (Ind.) lightweight, evened the score with Allie Stolz of Newark, N.J., in their ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Joyce, who had dropped a unanimous decision to Stolz last November, took the return bout by a split vote.
TOKYO, Feb. 15--There are increasing indications that Allied Headquarters does not intend to allow the Japanese to retain their petroleum refining industry. No policy has been announced but...

New York was invaded this week by a small army of ex-GI's who, on Tuesday evening, took over the premises at 108 West Forty-ninth Street, raised the insignia of Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force over the door and established Headquarters Restaurant.

News of two kinds has been coming out of India lately: political news, concerned with the ideas by which men live; economic news, concerned with the food by which they live or die. Most of this news is bad.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 15--A new method for obtaining prothrombin from blood plasma, a process of producing nicotinic acid in commercial quantities and a means for injecting therapeutic hormone solutions hypodermically are among the 442 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.
Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, made the folowing statement last night after the settlement of the steel strike:
A million new Presbyterian church members within three years is the goal set by the Rev. Dr. George E. Sweazey, secretary for evangelism of the Presbyterian Board of National Missions, he...

ALBANY, Feb. 15--The State Board of Regents ruled today that the merger of Columbia University's Medical and Dental Schools was "a matter of internal concern for the university itself," in which the board had interest only if courses should fall below prescribed standards.
At dusk last night a million lights blazed again in Times Square and the city had officially recovered--at least outwardly-- from the ten-day tugboat strike that ended late Wednesday.

Loss of woman's coat, suit and dress production resulting from the shutdown on Tuesday will be made pup in part by overtime work in (many shops, a survey of the industry showed yesterday. Shops with adequate supplies of piece goods which had been working overtime will be sorely pressed, however, to regain lost production.

Five teen-age youths, one a 14year-old boy said to be involved during the last month in the theft of fifty automobiles, and three others accused by police of five hold-ups and shooting a Flatbush storekeeper, were arrested yesterday in two sections of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--The first big reduction in the national debt in more than fifteen years was projected by the Treasury today as the debt rolled to a record high of $279,496,766,104.49, an average of $1,991.52 for each American.

STOWE, Vt., Feb. 16--Heavy winds that swept from Mount Mansfield much of its four inches of new powder snow today threatened to force postponement of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's downhill, slalom and combined championship, scheduled for the week-end on the precipitous "Nose Dive" trail.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15 (AP)-- Ben Hogan, the Texas icicle who works out of Hershey, Pa., took a two-stroke lead on the field in the New Orleans open golf tournament today with a 3-under-par 35, 34-- 69 for a 36-holo total of 140.
Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale, a two-piano team new to New York, played last night in Town Hall not only with skilled musicianship but also with enormous good-will for music of their own time.

ALBANY, Feb. 15-The extraordinary investigation of crime in Albany County, which was ordered by Governor Dewey twenty-six months ago, ended officially today with the disbandment of the grand jury, and a charge by George P. Monaghan, special prosecutor, that it was impossible to obtain a fair and impartial trial panel in the county.

Col. Thomas W. Jones, QMC, commanding officer of the Quartermaster Purchasing Office in New York, was presented with the Legion of Merit yesterday by Maj. Gen. Clifford L. Corbin, former Director of Procurement, Office of the Quartermaster General in Washington.

DES MOINES, Feb. 15--Secretary of Agriculture Anderson flew to this center of the corn-fed hog farming industry today to lay before hog producers a Government proposal for curtailing the production of heavyweight hogs in order to make more grain available to feed the hungry in Europe.

This year will mark the greatest expansion of the United CigarWhelan Stores Corporation, which, by the end of 1947, is expected to be operating on the basis of at least $100,000,000 annual sales volume, Walter G. Baumhogger, president, said last night at the Victory Dinner tendered,its merchandise suppliers by the corporation at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 15--Ismail Sedky Pasha, 70 years old, and dictatorial former Premier who is an advocate of more speed and directness in negotiating for the termination of the British occupation of Egypt, was reliably reported tonight...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--Miss Margaret Truman, daughter of the President and Mrs. Truman, was guest of honor tonight at a ball given by Mrs. Georga Mesta at the latter's home here. Some 250 young people from official and diplomatic society attended the dance, which was preceded by a dinner at the Sulgrave Club for out-of-town guests.
LONDON, Feb. 15--Italians claim to have found the authentic original map of the so-called "Wilson line" delimiting a frontier between Italy and Yugoslavia, and this map will be offered to the...

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 15--On the eve of the first competition for the Yankees here, a scrub game tomorrow, and with emphasis on the declaration that "it is only in a game that you can judge a ballplayer," Manager Joe McCarthy today revealed that his most, serious problem is the disposition of
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--A four-week strike at the mills of the United States Steel Corporation will end at midnight Sunday, and the rest of the industry is expected to return to production soon...

A.P. Waxman's musical production, "The Duchess Misbehaves," featuring Audrey Christie, George Tapps, Paula Laurence and Joey Faye, will call it quits after tonight's performance, the fifth, at the Adelphi Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--President Roosevelt, after reading an intercepted and incomplete text of the final Japanese reply to the United States on the eve of Pearl...
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 15-- The marriage of Miss June Schuyter Patterson, daughter of Mrs. Irene L. Patterson of this community and Lieut. Comdr. Schuyler B.

MIAMI, Feb. 15 (AP)--Sheer Luck, a chestnut filly from the Diamond Stable who was beaten in her last two attempts against stake performers of her sex, surprised a gathering of 18,737 at Hialeah Park today by winning the featured Thoroughbred Purse at $63.70 for $2.

Five young sailors, all of them awaiting general court martial, sawed their way out of a Navy brig in Brooklyn early yesterday , morning, jumped twenty-five feet to the ground, clipped barbed wire and escaped. The sailors, ranging in age from 19 to 21, had been detained at the Naval Receiving Station and Armed Guard Center, at First Avenue and Fifty-second Street.
The decision of the Treasury to pay off nearly three billion dollars of maturing obligations in cash in the next month had some interest yesterday in Wall Street as a portent.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Feb. 15--Hans Frank, former Governor General of Poland; former Field Marshal Gen. Wilhelm Keitel, once Germany's top general, and Alfred Rosenberg, former Commissar for Ostland territories, were linked today to the murder of millions of Russians, Poles, Yugoslavs and Czechoslovaks in evidence by the Soviet prosecution before the International Military Tribunal.
CHUNGKING, Feb. 15--The Chinese Communist party today demanded joint control of Manchuria with the Kuomintang and other "parties, groups and non-partisans"...
CHICAGO, Feb. 15--May rye fluctuated most erratically today on the Board of Trade, with the high and low prices of the day made within five minutes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--President Truman and James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State, declared at their press conferences today that they were responsible for the issuance of the State Department's Blue Book describing the spread of nazism in Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--The new wage-price policy provides a more liberal basis of computing cost-of-living wage increases but will expand the Government's administrative job of passing on these increases, according to the general view here.

First Lieut. Kenneth A. N. Woodelton, pilot of a Havoc light bomber, who was previously reported missing, lost his life on July 3, 1945, on Mindora Island, Philippine Islands, according to word received by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. George O. Woodelton of 33-46 Seventy-third Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.
OTTAWA, Feb. 15--Royal Canadian Mounted Police, striking suddenly, detained at least twenty-two men today as the Government launched an investigation into the...

A soldier and a sailor, respectively the 9,999,999th and the 10,000,000th visitors to the Service Men's Lounges maintained by the Travelers Aid Society of New York, received complete civilian outfits yesterday morning in a ceremony in the lounge of the Pennsylvania Station.
LONDON, Feb. 15--There is serious concern in London over reports from Germany of an impending fusion of the Communist and Social Democratic parties in Berlin and the Russian occupation zone.

Despite the loss of business on Tuesday, occasioned by Mayor O'Dwyer's shutdown order, retail sales here this week showed a gain in dollar volume over the like period last year. Estimates indicated department store sales were about 10 per cent higher. This, however, compares with a rise of 33 per cent in the previous week.

New household products incorporating safety features that should prevent homemakers from bumping their heads on wall can openers or falling out of upper story windows while, hanging out the wash were demonstrated yesterday to representatives of the Newark Safety Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--President Truman awarded today the Medal for Merit to W. Averell Harriman of New York, resigned Ambassador to the Soviet Union, "for execeptionally distinguished and meritorious conduct in the performance of outstanding services to the United States."

ROME, Feb. 15--Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York, awaiting next week's ceremonies that will make him a Cardinal saw Pope Pius XII today and celebrated mass in St. Peter's as the first of a series of three masses he intends to celebrate in the churches where he said his first masses when he was ordained thirty years ago.

The stock market responded yesterday with increased vigor to the greater optimism in all quarters over the nearness of settlement of the wage-price controversy, which has paralyzed the nation's basis industries.

PARIS, Feb. 15--Felix Gouin, President of the French Provisional Government, was applauded for several minutes after his address today in which he explained that France's appeal to the United States would be for help to help herself.

Thomas J. Patterson, Budget Director, announced yesterday that the budget estimates of 109 departments and agencies of the city government wanted a total increase of $153,029,812 for the 1946-47 fiscal year.

Shoe factories will not be able to continue operations unless immediate action is taken by the Civilian Production Administration and the Office of Price Administration to channel needed yardages of shoe fabrics to producers, W. W. Stephenson, executive vice president of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15--Sound management and effective unionism do not fit together at important points and one or the other must be modified to achieve workable mutual relations, Dr. E. Wright Bakke, director of the Labor and...
Thermometers in the city went back to registering winter temperatures yesterday after the record-breaking high of 61 degrees at 1:52 P.M. on Thursday.

The high bid that won for W. C. Langley Co. and Union Securities Corporation an award of 50,000 shares of new preferred stock of Iowa Power and Light Company caused an anxious morning yesterday for its Chioago-bound custodian on the Twentieth Century Limited.

A Bronx shoe manufacturer, convicted in War Emergency Court yesterday of violating the ceiling price on nylon stockings, won a revocation of his sentence from Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate after he had piqued the court's curiosity with a bizarre tale of how he had acquired-the stockings.
New Yorkers will have their last opportunity to contribute to the Victory Clothing Collection for overseas relief this week-end, it was announced yesterday by collection officials.
Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 17.9 per cent in January over the same month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Enough nylon stockings are being made to supply every woman in America who needs a pair, but because of the distribution methods being used by department stores "a few women are getting many pairs of nylons and others are going without," Roy E. Tilles, president of Gotham Hosiery Company, Inc., declared yesterday.

Because of the huge number of applications by veterans seeking housing accommodations in converted military installations at the former Coast Guard Station at Manhattan Beach and the former Army base at Fox Hills, S.I., the State Division of Housing has set up a "point system" for the selec tion of tenants, it was disclosed yesterday.

MIAMI, Feb. 15--With the possible exception of a paddock at a racetrack, there is perhaps no place like a baseball spring training camp, where an "inside tip" can gain such tremendous momentum and in such an incredibly short space of time.

All the yacht racing rules are to be put through a sieve, their many complications cleared and a new and simplified edition put forth. That was decided last night at the annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union.

LONDON, Feb. 15--Three of the seven or eight Assistant Secretaries General who will help Trygve Lie of Norway in running the United Nations Organization are expected to be named tomorrow, with the Administration post going to Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Kansas State College, if he accepts.

Pay increases of 20 cents an hour for drivers of Fifth Avenue buses in the event of a decision permitting one-man operation of the vehicles in present arbitration proceedings between the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, were demanded yesterday by Harry Sacher, counsel for the union.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15--The New England Public Service Company, Augusta, Me., today advised the Securities and Exchange Commission that its subsidiary, the Central Maine Power Company, will file a refinancing plan with the commission.

A new water-mix oil enamel that dries to a glossy finish--said to be the first product of its kind developed by the paint industry-- was demonstrated to the press yesterday afternoon by the Glidden Company at the Hotel Commodore. Called "Spred Luster," the paint already has been introduced to the Chicago market and is expected to reach retail dealers here in about six weeks.

ALBANY, Feb. 15--Charged by Governor Dewey with devising a plan to make medical care more available to all classes of people, the Temporary State Commisison on Medical Care was hopelessly split today as it submitted a majority...

The establishment of special "courts of industry," paralleling regular courts of law, to serve as possible solutions for industrial conflicts and strikes was suggested here last night by Dr. James Creese, president of Drexel Institute of Technology, Philadelphia, at the annual dinner meeting of the Alumni Association of Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, N.J.

New Yorkers cannot have the misgivings about providing a temporary site for a world capital that some of their Westchester and Fairfield County neighbors have about providing a permanent site. If we merely counted heads, office floor space and dwelling units we could swallow UNO and hardly notice it.

A new one-year labor contract between the Newspaper Guild of New York and THE NEW YORK TIMES was signed yesterday afternoon by representatives of the union and the newspaper at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

DETROIT, Feb. 15--New optimism prevailed in the General Motors Corporation strike situation tonight following the first meeting of the so-called "first teams" representing each side in the tie-up, now eighty-seven days old.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 15-- India's food situation seems to be rapidly deteriorating. Tomorrow the Viceroy, Viscount Wavell, is scheduled to make a radio address that probably will summarize his Views on famine prospects.
President Truman's long-deferred Executive Order on wages and prices, and his accompanying statement, constitute an advance over recent policy in two respects.
This statement was issued here yesterday by Robert R. Wason, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, on the new wage-price policy:

Lorraine. Ohio, sold yesterday $650,300 of bonds to a syndicate headed by Fox, Reusch Co. The bonds, all designated by the winning bid, were awarded on the following basis: $610,000 of sewer bonds at 100.565 and $40,300 of street and sewer bonds at 100.30. The bonds will mature on Nov. 1, 1947 to 1961.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP)--Bombgashed London was urged to "get cracking" tonight in preparation for the "austerity" Olympics of 1948.
Eleven applicants have been proposed for admission to member firms of the New York Stock Exchange on or about March 1, the Exchange's weekly bulletin reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--The relative efficacy of atomic bombs and ten-ton blockbusters in bombing downtown New York was debated today before the Senate Special Committee on Atomic Energy.

The advance party of the Secretariat of the United Nations Organization is expected to arrive in New York not later than Thursday and will occupy temporary offices at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was learned yesterday.

Leslie MacMitchell, Elmore Harris, Fred Sickinger and New York University's mile and two-mile relay teams, undefeated at their specialties this indoor track season, will lead a big parade of stars to the starting marks in the New York Athletic Club games at Madison Square Garden tonight.

LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP)-- Dr. Julius I. Foust, president emeritus of the Woman's College at Greensboro of the University of North Carolina, died in a hospital here today. His age was 80. He had spent the last few winters here.

The 6,000-ton anti-aircraft cruiser Juneau, mounting sixty guns ranging from 20-millimeter to 5inch main batteries and incorporating so many war-developed structural improvements that she represents virtually a new class of warship, became an official unit of the Atlantic Fleet yesterday in a commissioning ceremony at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

Net profit of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc. and its subsidiaries amounted to $4,367,000 for the three months ended last Dec. 1, after providing $4,300,000 for Federal income taxes and $150,000 for contingencies, according to the report released today.
Sales of properties either for improvement or occupancy by the new owners featured realty deals reported yesterday on the west side.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15-- Diana Productions, the Fritz LangJoan Bennett-Walter Wanger organization, which produced "Scarlet Street," has scheduled "Winchester 73," a Western screen story by Stuart Lake, as the company's next film for Universal. Joan Bennett will be starred and Mr. Lang will direct.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission today ordered a consolidated hearing to consider the twenty-four applications for new frequency modulation (FM) radio stations in the New York City area. The date of the hearing will be announced later.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 15-- Philip O. Chalmers of Port Huron, Mich., chief of the Division of Brazilian Affairs of the United States State Department, died today of pneumonia after a brief illness.
Sidney Rossman of 22 East Sixty-second Street, president of the Lexington School for the Deaf, died yesterday in the Gotham Hospital. His age was 61.

LONDON, Feb. 15-A clause in the Anglo-American air transport agreement, recently signed in Bermuda, guaranteeing to United States air lines the right to use landing fields in the United Kingdom constructed with American funds was included primarily to make the accord more acceptable to the American public, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)-- Secretary Anderson has directed aides to re-examine food production goals set for 1946, to ascertain whether it is possible to produce more food to help relieve world shortages.

STOWS, Vt., Feb. 16--Kristofer Berg, the stocky Norwegian skier who competed in all the major races in Europe before the war, gave a remarkable exhibition of courage, steadiness and judgment of pace in outclassing a field of forty-five outstanding down-hill racers in the opening phase of the...

LONDON, Feb. 16--The beginnings of the foundation for the United Nations Trusteeship Council which may ultimately supervise the fate of hundreds of millions of dependent people have been laid at the UNO meeting but, as everyone expected, the major problems connected with the issue remain and will have to be resolved outside UNO.

ANOTHER new Chinese Moon Almanac has just rolled off the presses. For the "Year of the Dog," which began on Feb. 2, it will constitute a guide to millions of Chinese peasants in marrying off their children...

The trend toward nationalization of public utilities in Great Britain and continental Europe is expected to meet opposition in Belgium tomorrow when the people go to the polls to decide this prime issue in their first post-war elections.

Operators figured in seven realty transactions reported yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx. A site on East Twenty-fourth, Street was sold by a holding company for a new business building, and a well-known office structure on East l49th Street also changed hands.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16-- The Viceroy, Viscount Wavell, proclaiming the famine danger in a broadcast to the Indian people, called tonight for a twelve-ounce daily grain ration throughout India and asked for sacrifices by rich and poor to avert starvation.

Two large plots in Ridgewood, N.J., have been purchased by an investor who plans to erect gardentype apartments, according to J. Rudolph Kirsch, broker in the transaction. The parcels, 300 by 150 feet and 146 by 180 feet, are on East Ridgewood Avenue, just west of the Ridgewood High School.

Members of the planning commission of the United Nations Organization, due here soon to select parts of Westchester County and Fairfield County in Connecticut, for a world capital, will slice into one of the highest-priced residential areas in the country, it was learned yesterday.

Leslie MacMitchell won the Baxter Mile, as expected, but last night, for the first time since he came home from the wars to reassert his supremacy over the eight-furlong field, he had really to go all out for victory.

LONDON, Feb. 16--United Nalions delegates, who this week chose the Westchester-Fairfield district for their permanent home, nave already plunged into what is expected to become a heated argument over the kind of world capital they should build. The conflicting views have been characterized as "Global City" versus "College Campus."

In an outline of new building methods and improvements for apartments to be utilized by his company under its post-war expansion plans, Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, took note yesterday of hesitancy on the part of many private builders to go ahead with their plans and asserted that his company had found representatives of the Office of Price Administration to be "fair" in determining new rental ceilings.

Two firemen were severely injured, three stores wrecked and two others damaged, traffic tied up and several shops shut off for business yesterday morning after a four-alarm fire broke out in the art supply store of Rappaport Eller at 163-44 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 16-- Army's basketball team evened its season's wins and losses at six each today by defeating the University of Pittsburgh quintet, 56 to 42, in a loosely played game, before a capacity crowd in the spacious West Point field house.

Despite the shutdown ordered by Mayor O'Dwyer last Tuesday, retail trade here last week showed an increase over the like period of last year. Department store volume was estimated as about 10 per cent greater.

A group of seventy-five doughty husbands, clutching corsages and other gifts, braved below-freezing temperatures and bitter winds yesterday at Pier 64, North River, waiting for the Army transport Santa Paula, inbound from Southampton, England, to dock with 251 British brides and 123 children.

New Zealand, with a population of about 1,000,000 and an area about twice that of the State of New York, passed a Social Security Act in 1938. Provisions were made for the mentally afflicted, maternity benefits, general hospitalization--all gradually introduced. By 1941, medicines were provided and limited medical service was extended. Home nursing was added in 1944.

SPIKES of tall bloom for the background are often the finishing touch to the flower border the gardener is plan ning at this time of year, and that's where hollyhocks enter the picture. Reflecting primarily huge purchasing power and the recurrence of a buying wave possibly stimulated by inflation psychology, retail trade so far this year has greatly exceeded preliminary estimates. Topping the long series of new high sales each month last year, nation-wide department store volume since Jan. 1 has already risen 15 per cent over 1945.

The senior circuit has its Green Book, the junior one its Red Book.

To make commercial flying safer than it is, Henry Busignies of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, comes out with "navar" and a world-wide system of long-range radio beacons called "naviglobe." He revealed his plans at a conference held recently in Washington.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19--A National Labor Relations Board election on March 4 will determine whether the Screen Players Union, an independent organization, or the American Federation of Labor Screen Extras Guild shall be the bargaining agent for some 3,400 extras in the movie industry.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Feb. 19-- Protestant and Orthodox church leaders were arriving today in this city, where Calvin and Knox nurtured they doctrines of Protestantism, preparing to establish what they hope will be a permanent world-wide Protestant and Orthodox church organization.

Mr. and Mrs. Fairfield Osborn of 207 East Sixty-first Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Josephine Adams, to William Matson Roth, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Philip Roth of San Francisco. The wedding is planned for mid-April.

Only yesterday, it seems, people were running about in somewhat breathless enthusiasm to be the first to tell their neighbors about a sprightly new magazine. Apparently we have somehow lost track of the years.

Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that he had sold by allotment $25,000,000 of New York City revenue bills dated Feb. 21 and payable on April 26, and carrying interest of 0.50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--President Truman told Congress and the country today that he considered it "a moral obligation of the United States to look after the welfare of Philippine Army veterans."

BALTIMORE, Feb. 20 (AP)--A Maryland Circuit Court judge held invalid and unconstitutional today the State Racing Commission's Rule 146 (D), which makes trainers completely responsible if drugs are administered to their horses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Unemployment among veterans who are seeking work is about three times as great as among civilians in the labor market, Gen. Omar N. Bradley, administrator of Veterans Affairs, said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (U.P.)-- The first contingent of a taxi caravan of war veterans arrived here tonight to seek the Government's help in obtaining licenses to operate cabs in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, told the Senate Naval Affairs Committee today that Edwin W. Pauley had done "a good job" as American member of the Reparations Commission and he would give him "the benefit of the doubt" on his oil record.

BERLIN, Feb. 20 (U.P.)--Brig. Gen. Robert A. McClure today publicly branded Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler a "tool" of the Nazi party and said the famed German symphony conducter would not be permitted to return to his former post as director of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra.

Total resources of the 272 banks and trust companies with New York State charters rose to a high record of $24,168,737,000 at the end of 1945, and net profits established a new top of $164,601,000, compared with $132,256,000 a year before, a compilation by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, issued yesterday, showed.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--Prompt enactment of bills providing for the uniform classification of accounts and prohibiting boycotts, coercion and intimidation in the insurance business was urged today by Superintendent of Insurance Robert E. Dineen in his preliminary report to the Legislature.

MADRID, Feb. 20--Flatly proclaiming himself a monarchist and describing monarchy as Spain's traditional governmental form, Generalissimo Francisco Franco predicted today that when the Spanish people were eventually consulted on the type of regime that they desired for the future, they would vote for a king.

A contemporary version of the expansive farmhouse kitchen is offered in a new model unit that will be put on view today at Altman's. Presented in collaboration with House Beautiful, the setting is designed to help homemakers decide whether a kitchen should be a comfortable living area for the homemaker or merely an efficient work area.

Ignoring the weakness in the stock market, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rallied yesterday from the break experienced on Monday and closed 20 to 30 points net higher.

Harris of the Royal Air Force who, as former head of the RAF Bomber Command, directed British "saturation" raids on Nazi industrial centers, arrived here yesterday for a short visit in this country, during which he will receive the Distinguished Service Medal from Gen. Mrs. Helen Sobel and Miss Ruth Sherman of New York played brilliantly against a strong field of women bridge players yesterday to take a strong lead in defense of the Wainwright women's pair championship of the Eastern tournament, being held at the Park Central Hotel. The Republic Steel Corporation in its annual statement for 1945 issued yesterday to stockholders, disclosed a net income after all charges, including taxes, of $9,543,443, equal to $1.36 a share of common stock. This compares with $10,130,296, or $1.44 a share the year before.

Enthusias bounded to "skihigh" proportions for the Washington's Birthday holiday period, starting tomorrow, as the recent heavy snowstorm left in its wake deep covers ranging from six to twenty inches in the skilands, extending from Pennsylvania through New York and New Jersey and including the six New England States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--President Truman made it possible today, unless unexpected difficulties should develop in Congress, for the Navy to rebuild Agana, 300-yearold capital of Guam, and other towns razed by American forces when they recaptured this island base from the Japanese in July, 1944.

Dr. William Malcolm, former medical missionary in China, died Tuesday night in his home at 956 Fifth Avenue after a brief illness. His age was 85.

The 214th anniversary of the birth of George Washington will be marked with a parade, religious services and other gatherings here tomorrow. Banks and public schools will be closed and the Exchanges will be closed both tomorrow and Saturday.

MEXICO CITY, March 12--The Mexican oil industry has accumulated a deficit of 1,000,000,000 pesos ($200,000,000) since the time of expropriation, Manuel A. Hernandez, editor of El Economista, declares in an article published today.
Aluminum summer furniture bids fair to offer stiff competition to orthodox wrought iron lines on the basis of retail orders pouring in to manufacturers, it was learned yesterday.

Former Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins who was appointed by Governor Dewey to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Surrogate James A. Foley was inducted yesterday from the same bench where his life-long friend and predecessor had presided for a quarter century.

Thus exclaims Vincent Sheean in words that sound more like a prayer and a protest than like a prophecy. The words are a few out of the great many that comprise his newest volume of personal introspection, reporting and philosophizing upon the sad state of the world.
